headline: Casemiro has done what Manchester United wanted – but there's a catch
body: If anybody in Manchester United's squad will be determined to prove his doubters wrong this season, it is Casemiro.

After an excellent debut season at Old Trafford in 2022/23, the Brazilian regressed at an alarming rate last season. He was criticised relentlessly, so much so that suggestions of retirement were mooted.

Turning 33 next February, it would be in United's best interests to try and offload him before the end of this summer's transfer window. But with another two years remaining on his deal, they are unlikely to receive offers in the region they are looking for.

Though United must bring in a new holding midfielder before the window closes in a little over a fortnight's time, the dream scenario would be for Casemiro to defy his critics and get back to his very best.

He has started each of the Reds' six games in preparation for Friday night's Premier League opener against Fulham, meaning he is a shoo-in to start for the visit of the Cottagers. He captained the side throughout pre-season and even helped himself to a goal in the 3-2 win over Real Betis at the Snapdragon Stadium in San Diego.

Despite being drafted in from Real Madrid two years ago to add steel and grit to United's midfield - something which he did excellently in his first season at the club - he has often been reliable in an attacking sense. He has 12 goals and nine assists in 84 competitive appearances for the club.

Although he is a player of a defensive profile, he is often hungry to get forward and pop up in advanced positions. He linked up superbly with Amad on the edge of the penalty area in Saturday's Community Shield clash with Manchester City, playing a key hand in what very nearly led to United scoring the game's opening goal in the first half.

He often ventured forward in pre-season, too, giving United an extra body when they attempted to attack the opposition's penalty area. As a caveat, it must be highlighted pre-season friendlies are not played at full throttle, but you can only make a judgement on what you see in front of you.

In Casemiro's case, he deserves credit where credit's due for his performances over the last four weeks. However, he has looked better going forwards than he has at attempting to protect the back-four.

headline: Sir Jim Ratcliffe has just doubled down on the Glazers' best decision at Manchester United
body: Manchester United players must walk past journalists to leave Wembley Stadium and the best interactions with squad members are often produced in the mixed zone.
Once a game is finished, journalists have a choice between attending the press conference or the mixed zone, but the MEN send two reporters to cover United matches.
Having two dedicated reporters at a game means nothing is missed and I was present in the mixed zone on Saturday after United lost in the Community Shield on penalties.

Asking each player if they'd be kind enough to spare a minute to chat can be a thankless task, especially after a defeat, and nobody was willing to speak as they darted for the team bus at Wembley, but most of the squad had the decency to politely decline the request.

There are some players in the United dressing room - and at every other Premier League club - who choose to blank journalists as they walk through the mixed zone, which is obviously their prerogative, but having the decency to politely say 'not today' is always appreciated.
Journalists don't look for sympathy when they are ignored in the mixed zone - it's part of the job and that's not what this article is about - but politely declining goes a long way.
Christian Eriksen and Harry Amass were the first to walk through the mixed zone after the Community Shield and both had the courtesy to decline a request to speak.

I have never seen academy graduate Scott McTominay ignore a reporter and he politely said 'no' when he left, while Harry Maguire, Jonny Evans, Diogo Dalot, Kobbie Mainoo and Toby Collyer were among the others to politely gesture 'no', or say 'no thanks' as they exited.
The likeable Andre Onana, who often volunteers to speak after games, did the same, while the South American squad members were approached by Spanish-speaking journalists.

Casemiro briefly exchanged a few words of Spanish with a journalist and Erik ten Hag, who had conducted his press conference, walked through next. The Dutchman gave a nod to reporters and had a warm embrace with City defender Nathan Ake, who left at the same time.
Ten Hag was generous with his time before the pre-season tour of the United States and exclusively spoke to Manchester-based reporters after facing Rosenborg and Rangers, which was appreciated.
When the majority of the United squad have walked through the mixed zone and none have stopped to speak, a reporter's hopes of engaging with a player for quotes are dampened.
However, before leaving the mixed zone and abandoning the pursuit, the natural thing to do is to think about which players have departed already and who might be remaining in the dressing room.
On Saturday, one of the last players to walk through was Bruno Fernandes and he said: "Sorry, I've spoken to everybody else [two other broadcasters] already," with a sympathetic look on his face.
Fernandes is regarded as the best talker at United by Manchester-based journalists, who see him up close every week, and it was typical of his character not to blank a request to chat.

Many in the national media questioned why Fernandes was given the captain's armband last summer but nobody who closely follows United echoed those sentiments because he was the only choice to succeed Maguire.
Fernandes embodies what being a United player means. He has given his best years to the club during an up-and-down period and deserves the new contract he's set to sign.

"I will be here until I've said, the club needs to want me," said Fernandes about his future after the final home game of last season. "I feel the club wants me to be part of the future, so as I said, I don't want to be a player the club doesn't want to have. I will go if for some reason they don't want me."
Safeguarding Fernandes' future was always going to be the best piece of business United could do this year and the 28-year-old will be rewarded with higher wages in his new deal.
Although Sir Jim Ratcliffe is attempting to lower the wage bill, an exception must be made for the club captain, who has been worth his weight in gold over the last few seasons.

Fernandes has been outstanding on the pitch and has been a terrific ambassador away from it, which was highlighted again after the FA Cup final when a story emerged claiming he offered to pay for a staff trip to Wembley out of his own pocket following Ratcliffe's cost-saving cuts.
There is a misconception about Fernandes' personality in the national media due to his occasional petulance with referees during matches but that shouldn't detract from who he truly is.
Manchester United are fortunate to have Fernandes and there is no doubt about that.

headline: Erik ten Hag gets ultimate Lisandro Martinez proof before Matthijs de Ligt Man United transfer
body: Manchester United's pre-season came to an end in disappointing fashion on Saturday as Manchester City beat them 7-6 on penalties to win the Community Shield.

While the defeat is unlikely to haunt the United fans nor Erik ten Hag for too long, there were still things the Reds' backroom staff will have learned from the narrow defeat. The most poignant being how valuable Lisandro Martinez is to the team's defence.

With defenders dropping like flies in the build-up to the clash at Wembley Stadium, Ten Hag was able to call upon Martinez at left-back to allow Harry Maguire and Jonny Evans the luxury of playing in more familiar positions. Such versatility could prove crucial for the Reds this season particularly when the likes of Tyrell Malacia and Luke Shaw are still trying to overcome their injury problems.

It is not surprising that United struggled to settle defensively last season without Martinez being in the starting line-up on a consistent basis. With Matthijs de Ligt and Leny Yoro joining this summer, it would be easy to cast the Argentine to one side as just another player but this weekend he proved how integral he remains for the Reds.

If United are going to be successful this season it shall also be dependent on the fitness of Bruno Fernandes. Playing in the unfamiliar false nine position, the Portuguese was once again one of the standout players for United.

With every passing performance, you can see how the captaincy at Old Trafford has aided Fernandes. Before, the 29-year-old would get too caught up in shenanigans which made him an easy target but that side of his game appears to be simmering down now as the weight of the armband shows its positive impact.

His performance at Wembley was a fine example of this but also begs the bigger question of why Fernandes was not named among the 'untouchable' players at Old Trafford at the beginning of the transfer window. However, the new contract on the table for Fernandes should put any concerns to bed about his future.

The final big talking point from the traditional pre-season opener revolved around Marcus Rashford. The academy product promised he would come back stronger than ever after missing out on the England Euro 2024 squad and suffering a poor season by his standards.

Rashford will wish he had gotten off to the perfect start when he mistimed his strike after being teed up by Alejandro Garnacho. headline: Wayne Rooney struggles seal Man United fate as 10-year prediction left in tatters
body: Wayne Rooney is already on the back foot as his managerial career sunk to a new low on Sunday.

Since being appointed Birmingham City manager in October 2023, Rooney has just two wins to his name. The Manchester United legend lasted just 83 days at St Andrews' before being sacked in January where he left Birmingham in the Championship bottom three, having been in the playoffs when he arrived.

Blues never recovered from their Rooney experiment and were relegated on the final day of the 2023/24 season, their first relegation from English football's top two tiers in 30 years. Rooney understandably took a break from management before news emerged that Plymouth Argyle had appointed him this summer.

And with all eyes on the touchline to see how the 38-year-old would fare in his second job in the Championship, he could not have got off to a worse start. The Pilgrims were smashed 4-0 against Sheffield Wednesday in their opening fixture of the 2024/25 campaign.

It was just what Rooney didn't need after his struggles at Birmingham and with so many critics waiting to pounce on any sign of failure in the early stages of his new job. It is why Rooney's comments back in February about managing Man United one day now look to be in tatters already.

"Managing Manchester United or Everton is the aim, these big jobs are where you want to get to," he said on Match of the Day, when working as an analyst for United's FA Cup game against Nottingham Forest.

"But it's a process. I have got to go through the steps and get myself back on track. I want to get myself back into management to make sure in the next 10 years I'm hopefully in a position to go into one of the big jobs."

No one can deny that Rooney has a wealth of knowledge when it comes to playing at the highest level. That experience will no doubt have influenced his employees and most United fans will want him to succeed.

Rooney's punditry work for the BBC during Euro 2024 and his time on the Overlap podcast with Gary Neville have shown him to be a likeable character who has more charisma than some will have had you believe.

But the warning signs are there when it comes to his abilities as a manager. No head coach in the Championship will have ever come under more scrutiny and the verdict so far is worrying for United's record goalscorer.

headline: Man United face immediate Matthijs de Ligt and Noussair Mazraoui concerns after transfers
body: Manchester United are set to complete the much-needed signings of Matthijs de Ligt and Noussair Mazraoui as Erik ten Hag desperately seeks defensive reinforcements.

The summer departures of Raphael Varane and Willy Kambwala alongside the long-term injury to Leny Yoro have left United scrambling to bolster their options in defence. And it looks like both De Ligt and Mazraoui will be joining Erik ten Hag's team in the nick of time.

United kick off their Premier League campaign in four day's time against Fulham where both new signings may need to be used. Ten Hag confirmed after the Community Shield that Harry Maguire has a knock whilst Lisandro Martinez started Saturday's game in his unnatural left-back position, with Luke Shaw and Tyrell Malacia unavailable.

But another immediate concern has emerged which United may need to address before facing the Cottagers on Friday. Both of United's potential new signings have seen very little match action in pre-season.

De Ligt has not played a single minute since returning from his post-Euro 2024 summer break. The Dutchman did not feature at all during the tournament in Germany with his last minutes coming in an international friendly against Canada on June 6.

Mazraoui meanwhile has played 24 minutes from the bench in a friendly against Duren on July 24 and 22 minutes against Tottenham on August 3. It means that both players will be some way off match fitness and may not have much time to adapt to the intensity of Premier League football.
One solution could be handing the pair minutes in a behind-closed-doors friendly. The game would need to take place sooner rather than later though with time running out before Friday's game.

If both players can get through their opening fixture unscathed, they will have another week to get towards full fitness before taking on Brighton. It's hard to see how either player will play the full 90 minutes against Fulham, but Ten Hag may be able to give them enough minutes to ease them in.

But United cannot afford to start the season badly and playing two players in positions which could leave them exposed will be a risk. If they can mitigate that risk then a problem area of the pitch will be strengthened significantly.

headline: Man United given Manuel Ugarte transfer 'green light' as three star players banished
body: Manchester United have been given a major boost to their hopes of signing Manuel Ugarte. The 23-year-old midfielder has been heavily linked with a move to Old Trafford this summer as Erik ten Hag looks to strengthen his options in the middle of the park.

Ugarte, who sees his contract at Les Parc des Princes expire in June 2028, featured 25 times for Paris Saint-Germain in Ligue 1 last season, providing three assists. Despite playing a key role in a title-winning domestic campaign, he struggled to force himself into Luis Enrique's side in the Champions League.

Once the Parisians had qualified for the knockout stages, the Uruguay international was sidelined. Nevertheless, after just 12 months in the French capital, Ugarte faces an uncertain future – and the Red Devils have emerged as potential suitors.

So much so that, according to L’Equipe journalist Loïc Tanzi, the United target has been banished from training, along with Nordi Mukiele and Danilo. The report states that the three could leave PSG before the transfer window slams shut at the end of this month.

According to the Mirror earlier this month, the Red Devils believe the French giants' asking price is too high and they will only re-enter negotiations if their demands are lowered. The report claims that PSG are eager to recoup the £51.4million they paid Sporting CP for Ugarte last summer.

Last week, Ten Hag called for patience on new signings. Speaking to reporters ahead of the Red Devils' clash against Manchester City in the Community Shield, the Dutchman claimed that his squad is in a 'good position'.

"When we have news, we will announce it," insisted Ten Hag. "You see the market is quite quiet still but we have done our business, we have done two deals. It is about timings and it is about the market options and [ensuring] in the right moment we do the right things."
When quizzed on the arrival of a new central midfielder, he added: 'I don't go into details where we are now with recruitment and what we are working on.
"We know what we are doing and I think we are in a good position with the squad. For you, just wait, be patient and in the right moment, we will tell you."

headline: Man United have major reason to avoid £33.7m Chelsea transfer hijack despite Casemiro plea
body: Manchester United have an open dialling line to Stamford Bridge amid uncertainty over Conor Gallagher's future. However, while clubs across Europe will be keeping a watchful eye on what unfolds for Gallagher over these next 24 hours or so, Ineos are best served ignoring their opportunity to hijack a move.

It seemed for all the world Gallagher would relocate to Spain this summer. Chelsea and Atletico Madrid agreed a £33.7million fee, but with the 24-year-old preparing to jet back to London, there are lingering question marks over that proposed transfer as key figures involved weigh up possible solutions.

The Gallagher deal has stalled following a completed £81.5million move for now-former Manchester City forward Julian Alvarez, while Chelsea have had Samu Omorodion and Joao Felix in their crosshairs in a triangle-like transfer saga featuring City and Atletico; one nothing to do with United despite their ongoing search for a midfielder.

Gallagher, as he underlined at Euro 2024 this summer, is a decent player in his own right. However, the ideal plan for United to strengthen their engine room is by finding direct cover and competition for Casemiro; they need an option who is first and foremost a tackler capable of operating as a one-man shield.

That's the best way for them to unleash Kobbie Mainoo and Bruno Fernandes when Casemiro is absent. Academy graduate Mainoo is more than able to sit deepest in a midfield three, but that detracts from his main qualities and for United to have a successful season, they really do need their superstar teenager purring.

Not to put an undue pressure on him, mind. Mainoo must be allowed to nurture at his own pace, which has been nothing short of meteoric to this stage, but he would benefit most of all without Casemiro by having someone of similar ilk alongside him - with Fernandes operating at No.10.

Mason Mount could eventually justify his £60million transfer fee and come good in his iconic No.7 shirt. However, when rubber-stamping his own move from Stamford Bridge last summer, that deal was an oversight for United as they did not particularly need to sign an attack-minded option at that juncture.

Mount was brought in to replace Christian Eriksen alongside Casemiro, before Mainoo assumed that mantle, with Gallagher's former teammate Mount often faring much better as a No.10 or wide attacker. United made an error in signing Mount for their intended purpose and they mustn't do the same with Gallagher.

In limbo, Gallagher will represent a relative bargain for someone, at £33.7million, after Chelsea opted to cash-in to ease PSR concerns and generate 'pure profit' for their own recruitment drive. United, though, simply have to plead ignorance to the chance that has inadvertently been presented to them.
They have to eek out what's left in the summer budget and put it towards more pressing matters.

headline: 'It was a no-brainer' - Aaron Wan-Bissaka explains transfer to West Ham from Manchester United
body: Aaron Wan-Bissaka has described his decision to join West Ham from Manchester United as a 'no-brainer'.
The one-year extension in Wan-Bissaka's contract was triggered in January and United were always open to selling him this summer to recoup a fee for the right-back.
It's understood United have received a fee of £15million for Wan-Bissaka and he's signed a seven-year contract in London, which is the city where he was born.
Wan-Bissaka's departure is allowing United to sign Noussair Mazraoui from Bayern Munich and the official announcement of the Morocco international's transfer is imminent.
After his exit from Old Trafford was confirmed on Tuesday afternoon, Wan-Bissaka said: “It was a no-brainer for me to join West Ham – I’m excited and happy to be here.
"It’s an amazing feeling to be back in London, and I’m excited for what’s coming. I was born here, so I know the ins and outs of London, which plays a big part in my life.
"So to be back playing in this city means a lot to me. I’m happy to be here, am grateful for the warm welcome, and I am excited to be playing for the club and will give it my all.

“I can’t wait to get on the pitch, get to know the players and push on from there. I see a team that is in it together, that will push each other to win, and a group that has got each others' backs through thick and thin, so being part of that and having that insurance helps a lot when you are surrounded by a good squad.”

West Ham's technical director, Tim Steidten, added: “I am delighted we’ve been able to get the deal to sign Aaron over the line. He’s exactly the type of player we’re looking to attract to this club in the prime years of his career.
“He’s an incredibly talented defender who we rate very highly – superb in one-on-one situations. He’s versatile too, which is clearly another positive.

"He’s played over 170 Premier League games during his career – he knows the division inside out. I’d like to personally thank the board for their continued backing to bring players of such quality to West Ham. It’s a really exciting time for us as we prepare for the start of the new season."
Wan-Bissaka was offensively limited during his time at United but his defensive quality in one-on-one situations was excellent and among the finest in the Premier League.
The Croydon-born full-back was outstanding in the Carabao Cup final in 2023 and FA Cup final in 2024 and his contributions in those games helped Ten Hag win two trophies in two years.
Wan-Bissaka has left United having made 190 appearances, scoring two goals for the club.

headline: Match of the Day announce two Ian Wright replacements as Man City legend lands new role
body: Former Arsenal star Theo Walcott and Man City legend Joe Hart are poised to step into the big shoes left by Ian Wright on Match of the Day.

The Arsenal legend, 60, announced his departure in December last year, more than 27 years after he made his debut on the iconic show. He had become a regular fixture alongside presenter Gary Lineker and the Premier League's all-time record goalscorer, Alan Shearer.

As the new Premier League season kicks off this week, the BBC have unveiled the two former Three Lions stars who will attempt to follow in his footsteps on the weekly highlights show, in an event with former host Des Lynam, joining the likes of Shearer, Shay Given and Micah Richards on the BBC's flagship show.

He said: "I'm stepping back having made great friends and many great memories. This decision has been coming for a while, maybe my birthday earlier this year fast tracked it a little, but ultimately it's time to do a few more different things with my Saturdays.

headline: Liverpool hijack, £51m breakthrough, transfer planning - Man United sent next signing verdict
body: The ongoing recruitment drive at Old Trafford kicked into gear shortly before Manchester United were beaten in the Community Shield by neighbours Manchester City on Saturday afternoon.
United pushed City all the way, before penalties were needed to separate them. However, the big news beneath the famous arch was not, necessarily, what happened on the pitch or from 12 yards.

In the build-up to that match, it was confirmed United had (finally) reached an agreement with Bayern Munich to sign Matthijs de Ligt and Noussair Mazraoui for £51.5million combined. The incoming duo - who are well known to United manager Erik ten Hag from their Ajax days - are due to follow Leny Yoro and Joshua Zirkzee to Old Trafford and take their overall spend close to the £150million-mark.

Before deals for De Ligt and Mazraoui were struck up, The Manchester Evening News understood United wanted to make at least three more major signings this summer. Getting more over the line will be shaped by player sales.
That means United might just have one final trick up their sleeve, in any case. Here, our reporters debate what the next should be for Dan Ashworth, Ineos and key figures behind the scenes;

With De Ligt and Mazraoui poised to be the next arrivals through the door at Old Trafford, attention now simply has to switch to strengthening the midfield. United have significantly strengthened their defence and added a new attacker to their ranks, meaning the midfield is the only department that has remained untouched.

As anticipated, it is proving to be the hardest transfer mission they wanted to solve this summer. They have been linked with a plethora of midfielders in recent weeks, but nothing has yet come to fruition.

Doubts have been cast about Casemiro's capacity to continue as United's chief holding midfielder, meaning they must strengthen that area of the squad before the window shuts. Manuel Ugarte is the best solution to solve that issue, but Paris Saint-Germain are not budging on their valuation of the player.

United need a defensive specialist to compliment the qualities of Kobbie Mainoo and Bruno Fernandes in midfield. However, true defensive specialists are not as common as they used to be, meaning links with Youssouf Fofana and Sander Berge are understandable.
However, by hook or by crook, United have got to find a midfielder from somewhere.

United may not feel the need to sign any more players following confirmation of arrivals for De Ligt and Mazraoui. With four new summer signings now through the door at Old Trafford, Ten Hag and Ineos have completed many of their transfer aims, but more players could still yet join.

A new forward and central defender have been acquired but a midfielder is still desperately needed, especially if Scott McTominay also seals an exit. Casemiro, despite links to Saudi Arabia, looks set to stay at the club but Ten Hag is still light in that department.

Berge, Fofana and Martin Zubimendi have all been linked but if I were Sir Jim Ratcliffe or Ashworth, Ugarte would be the priority. Though PSG do not look set to lower his asking price, it is a deal still worth pursuing as the Uruguay international has the ability to fit perfectly into United's midfield.
Casemiro and Mainoo are of a very different profile to Ugarte and thus he can provide Ten Hag with something he does not currently have in his squad.

Following the arrivals of defensive duo De Ligt and Mazraoui, United only really need to strengthen one area of the pitch - providing there are no other injuries or long absentees - before the end of the summer transfer window. And that position is in central midfield.

United have been linked with a number of players, including Ugarte, Fofana and Zubimendi, but if I were Sir Jim or Ten Hag, I would look at Crystal Palace's Adam Wharton. I have been saying all summer that United should pursue a move for the 19-year-old midfielder if they have the funds - and my stance on him has not changed. Wharton, for me, would be the perfect fit in that midfield.
If United cannot get Wharton, then Berge should be the alternative. The Norwegian has an abundance of Premier League experience and was one of Burnley's standout performers last season.

It's been a promising transfer window for United so far but there remains one area of the pitch which needs fixing. Casemiro played well in midfield against City but signing a younger and more athletic version of the Brazilian could be United's most important summer deal.
Ending interest in Ugarte was a blow but I understand the decision with the fees being reported for him. If they can get his asking price down then I think it would be a deal worth returning to.

If signing Ugarte is truly dead in the water then why not try to sign Zubimendi, if unlike Liverpool they can convince him to leave Real Sociedad. Burnley's Berge would be another alternative, although I'm much less convinced with that one as it's a big step up for him.

Central midfield should be United's top priority now they have added reinforcements to their defence. Berge continues to be linked with the Reds but I am not convinced he is the right man for the job.

Casemiro played well in the Community Shield but the proof will be in his performance come the Premier League's start date. Ugarte continues to be a player of interest for the Reds and perhaps he would be a good option but they will need PSG to lower their price tag somewhat before signing off on that deal.
AS Monaco's Fofana may also be a good option for United but what's definitively clear is that Ten Hag must add a midfielder to his squad before the season comes to an end.

One area of the United squad is screaming out for an addition before the end of the transfer window for me, and that is in central midfield. The signings of Yoro and De Ligt means that defence has been strengthened (despite Yoro's current injury), while the arrival of Zirkzee addresses the striker position.
Ten Hag now needs to look at who will play alongside Mainoo in midfield. United have been linked with several players in the position, including Ugarte and Berge.
Wharton of Crystal Palace is a good shout, but is likely to come with a big price tag, especially with Palace looking likely to lose Marc Guehi as well as Michael Olise.

The club decided not trigger an option in Sofyan Amrabat's loan deal this summer, but they could yet negotiate a lower price with Fiorentina. The player is said to be keen on the move back to Old Trafford, and if they can get a significant reduction, then it may be a wise move to bring him back as a shorter-term option.
Patience may mean a move for Wharton sometime in the future may be possible.

headline: Matthijs de Ligt and Noussair Mazraoui transfers will seriously impact five Man United stars
body: Manchester United's summer transfer window spending is set to take the next step up this week as Bayern Munich duo Matthijs de Ligt and Noussair Mazraoui prepare to join for a combined fee of £51.5m.
These deals signify United manager Erik ten Hag going to the old and familiar well of players he has worked with previously. Both men enjoyed brilliant spells under the Dutchman's coaching at Ajax.

The duo improved tremendously in Amsterdam during his reign with De Ligt particularly moving on to bigger and better things since. However, the pair have been left out in the cold at the Allianz Arena and now they are both seeking shelter with United.

As with all new arrivals to the club, there is bound to be a significant impact on the current playing squad. In this instance, there are five players who are set to be seriously affected by the two new recruits.
First up, is Aaron Wan-Bissaka. MEN Sport understands United's pursuit of De Ligt and Mazraoui was delayed while they waited for an agreement to be reached for the Englishman's exit.

The expectation is that West Ham United will snap up Wan-Bissaka with his medical currently being conducted in London as we speak. With that deal almost home and hosed, the next player to be impacted is Victor Lindelof.

United's Swede has been a valued member of the squad under several managers but there is a general acceptance that he does not have what it takes to take United back to the top of the domestic and European game. MEN Sport understands the Reds are actively pursuing a sale for Lindelof this summer and reports on Monday suggested his future is being discussed at a transfer meeting today.

While the first two United players are looking at the permanent exit door, the other three are looking at their playing time being altered one way or another. Tyrell Malacia suffered a horrendous injury last summer which kept him sidelined for the entirety of 2023/24.

The Dutchman has yet to return to the pitch but it is unlikely that he will be able to play regularly for United while he is recovering. With Mazraoui in the building, Malacia could be sent out on loan to regain his fitness away from the club which would surely be desired by all parties.

Malacia's left-back teammate Luke Shaw has a big season ahead of him after suffering with his own fair share of injuries in 2023/24. If fit, he is still the Reds' best left-back but he will be aware that his standards cannot slip if he is to stay there and this, unfortunately, includes ensuring his fitness remains knowing full well Mazraoui can do a job on that left-side.

Finally, Harry Maguire's role at United is most likely to alter with De Ligt's signature. Ten Hag is likely to preference a starting centre-back partnership of Martinez and De Ligt while Leny Yoro is out injured.

Once the Frenchman returns, Yoro is likely to move above Maguire in the pecking order with the England international having to settle for being back-up. With his contract expiring in 2025, it will be interesting to see whether the former Leicester City man is happy to once again wait for his chance in the starting XI.

headline: When Matthjis de Ligt and Noussair Mazraoui could make Man United debuts as medicals scheduled
body: Manchester United fans are waiting with bated breath for their latest arrivals to join the club.

Bayern Munich duo Matthijs de Ligt and Noussair Mazraoui are both currently on their way to Carrington to begin their medicals ahead of a combined £51.5m move to Old Trafford. Their signings have been facilitated thanks to an agreement being reached with West Ham for Aaron Wan-Bissaka's departure.

While De Ligt and Mazraoui conduct their medicals in Manchester, Wan-Bissaka is likely to be nearing the completion of his. In terms of the deal for De Ligt, this transfer has been a long time coming for Erik ten Hag.

The United boss wanted to make De Ligt one of his big summer purchases in the summer of 2022 during his first window at the club. However, a deal could not be completed and a move was postponed until the present day.

As for Mazraoui, the Moroccan was a player who flourished for Ajax during Ten Hag's tenure at the club. When the Dutchman left for United, the full-back decided to move to Bayern to make the next step in his career.

However, he has been frustrated by the lack of opportunities for minutes in Germany and is hopeful a reunion with Ten Hag will guarantee him more chances to impress. With the formalities the only thing standing in the way of both deals being officially announced, attention turns to when United fans will be able to see their new recruits in action for the first time.

MEN Sport understands at this stage that United will be able to complete the deals before the registration deadline for Friday's opener against Fulham. This means that both Mazraoui and De Ligt could make their debuts at the Theatre of Dreams this weekend.

Considering the duo will have had less than a week to get up to speed with their new teammates prior to Fulham, potentially a more realistic debut date could be the trip to Brighton and Hove Albion on Saturday, August 24.

headline: Premier League prediction made by supercomputer - and it's very good news for Man United
body: A supercomputer has predicted the opening day of the Premier League season, and it's great news for Manchester United fans.

New data collated by BetVictor shows that United could be lining up yet another matchday one win against Fulham on Friday night. Analysis provided by this supercomputer has suggested that Erik ten Hag's squad are likely to secure three points against the London side, based on their incredible record on the opening day of the season.

United have won 21 of their 32 matches on the first day of the campaign, averaging 2.16 points per game (PPG). They've only lost five times in that remarkable spell, with six draws rounding off the data.

Ten Hag's side secured three points at Old Trafford on the opening day of last season as Raphael Varane nodded home from close range against Wolves. United's record against Fulham also makes for good reading – the Red Devils have only lost once at home against Friday's visitors since 2003, albeit that defeat did come last season.

On the other hand, Manchester City aren't as fortunate with their matchday one record, averaging just 1.85 PPG over 26 matches since 1992. The reigning champions have won 14, drawn six and lost six of their opening day games in the Prem.

However, half of those victories have come under Pep Guardiola, who has won seven of his eight matches at the beginning of a new campaign. City have scored 19 goals and conceded just three under the Catalan on the opening day. They'll be hoping to improve that impressive record against Chelsea at Stamford Bridge on Sunday, live on Sky Sports.

Sam Boswell, spokesperson of BetVictor, said: "The new Premier League season is an exciting time for all fans across the division, with each team starting from a level playing field. Hopes will be high for many, and Manchester United supporters should take confidence from their previous performances on the first game of the season – no team since 1992 has earned more points on Gameweek 1.

headline: Frenkie de Jong's Man United transfer stance still backed up by girlfriend's Instagram hint
body: Frenkie de Jong has expressed he is content at Barcelona, dismissing rumours of a potential move to Manchester United.

And that echoes the sentiments of his girlfriend when the Red Devils previously pursued him. His partner Mikky Kiemeney had used social media to demonstrate their happiness in Spain when United first showed interest back in 2022.
The social media influencer shared a video of the couple wake surfing, captioning it: "Meanwhile... living our best life." She also added alongside the clip: "Found another gem in Catalunya."
READ MORE:Man United see £42.9m transfer bid 'turned down' as surprise Diogo Dalot exit route emerges

As De Jong prepares for his sixth season with Barcelona, having missed Euro 2024 due to an ankle injury, speculation about a possible move to United has resurfaced. However, the Dutchman has confirmed his desire to stay at Barcelona, despite reports that the Spanish club might be willing to sell him for approximately £51m (€60m) plus additional payments, reports the Mirror.

With Barcelona heading into the 2024/25 season under new manager Hansi Flick, De Jong acknowledged that he and his family are happy in Barcelona and that he had a positive conversation with the German boss. "Staying at Barca? Yes, I'm very happy in Barcelona with my family, for sure," De Jong insisted.

"Hansi Flick wants me to be key? I talked to him. It was good," he added. The 27-year-old's potential move to United hit a standstill in 2022 despite an initial £56million agreement with Barcelona, with personal terms failing to be finalised.
Erik ten Hag imagined De Jong forming a formidable midfield duo with Casemiro at United, playing a crucial role in executing the "Ajax style" of football he is known for.

In a detailed discussion with Gary Neville for Sky Sports, Ten Hag exposed his strategy had De Jong signed: "It would have been Frenkie de Jong and Casemiro [in the middle]," he stated, affirming, "They would really be connected with each other. They would be really complementary to each other. That's a typical player. If you want to play the Ajax style, you need that type of player."
United remain active in the transfer market, having secured the signings of Joshua Zirkzee and Leny Yoro, and are on the verge of acquiring Matthijs de Ligt and Noussair Mazraoui from Bayern Munich.

headline: Manchester United make fresh Old Trafford change as clear Marcus Rashford future clue given
body: Manchester United forward Marcus Rashford was the first player to be erected on the new poster at Old Trafford.
United have made routine changes to Old Trafford across the summer - certain parts of the stadium have been repainted and the players' tunnel has been renovated - and a new poster has been put up.

The glass on the outside of the East Stand is covered by a poster of United's players each season and Rashford was the first face to be printed opposite the Holy Trinity statue. United will begin the 2024/25 Premier League season against Fulham on Friday and workmen were present at Old Trafford on Sunday afternoon to erect the new poster.
Rashford is pictured in this season's new home kit and was joined on the posted by Mason Mount come Monday morning.

United were defeated by Manchester City in the Community Shield on penalties last weekend and Rashford started the game at Wembley but missed two big chances. Although the academy graduate is one of the most recognisable faces for fans around the world, his form dipped last season and he contributed just eight goals in all competitions.

Some United supporters suggested Rashford should have been sold this summer, but a move away wasn't on the cards and he will attempt to recapture his best form this term. Paris Saint-Germain have a longstanding interest in Rashford, who signed a new five year contract last summer, but are more likely to land Jadon Sancho in this window.

Mount was the next player to be printed on the poster and the MEN revealed last month that United weren't looking to sell the midfielder after a poor first season. There are staff within United who believe Mount had a false start last year due to injury and believe the new campaign is an opportunity for him to show why he was signed.

United were questioned for signing Mount last summer because Bruno Fernandes is considered undroppable as the No.10 and Kobbie Mainoo was on the cusp of the first-team. Mainoo became a consistent starter for United in the second half of the season and impressed for England at Euro 2024 while Mount was overlooked by the Three Lions again. Mount has not played for England since their World Cup quarter-final defeat to France in 2022.

headline: Matthijs De Ligt's five word message as Manchester United close in on double transfer
body: Matthijs de Ligt left Noussair Mazraoui waiting at Munich Airport this morning as the Bayern Munich players flew to England for their Manchester United medicals.

United have had two transfer offers totalling an initial £51.5million accepted by Bayern for the pair. They will pay £38.6m and £4.3m in add-ons while spreading the payments over three years for De Ligt and £12.9m for Mazraoui, with add-ons taking that deal to around £17m.

It comes a month after De Ligt verbally agreed personal terms during the European Championship. The club instead moved to sign Leny Yoro last month amid interest from Liverpool, Paris Saint-Germain and Real Madrid.
READ MORE:United face immediate De Ligt and Mazraoui concerns
READ MORE:When De Ligt and Mazraoui could make United debuts as medicals scheduled
Since then, they have also identified Mazraoui as a replacement for Aaron Wan-Bissaka, who is due to sign for West Ham United. Super-agent Rafaela Pimenta represents both players.

They are now closing in on completing moves to United and were spotted arriving at Munich's international airport earlier today. Mazraoui came in first, with De Ligt following and telling Sky Germany reporters awaiting them outside: "Noussair is waiting for me!"

The Dutch defender seemingly was delayed arriving at the airport, which meant their flight to Manchester took off roughly half an hour late. Medicals at United's training complex are scheduled for later today, and the club expects to conclude both deals early this week.

They are preparing to announce the double signing, with club sources saying the separate deals are progressing while acknowledging that visas will be needed for the two players. The deals are set to coincide with Wan-Bissaka departing, with United prepared to top-up the player's wages at West Ham until next summer, potentially to the tune of £5.6m.
The west London club could end up paying as much as £20m for the right-back. Wan-Bissaka signed for £50m from Crystal Palace five years ago.

headline: I've been in Ruud van Nistelrooy meetings at Man United – this is what he's really like
body: Ruud van Nistelrooy has been dubbed "the best" coach that ex-Manchester United star Tom Heaton has ever worked with after he arrived at Old Trafford as Erik Ten Hag's right-hand man.

Van Nistelrooy will be fondly remembered by Red Devils fans for his incredible five-year stint between 2001 and 2006, scoring 150 goals and bagging 30 assists alongside Ryan Giggs, Paul Scholes, Roy Keane and David Beckham.

Despite retiring from playing in 2012, the Dutchman has been incredibly busy in the world of football management - taking the reins of PSV Eindhoven U19s in 2018, spending a season at Jong PSV in 2021, and ultimately managing PSV's first team between 2022 and 2023 to a second-place finish in the Eredivisie.

And under Sir Jim Ratcliffe's ownership of Man United and a complete club reshuffle, the 48-year-old has returned to the North West to help guide the Red Devils to Premier League greatness once more, alongside Ten Hag. While the two were previously unknown to each other on a personal level, Ten Hag recommended Van Nistelrooy for the assistant manager job.

Van Nistelrooy's presence and knowledge of the game quickly impressed United bosses - earning him a contract until the summer of 2026. While he has been invaluable to United's current strikers and attacking midfielders, the former striker has also previously imparted his advice on decorated goalkeepers to help them understand their in-game competition - with Heaton dubbing him "the best" he's worked with.

The now 38-year-old, who has been in meetings with the Dutchman, admitted: "I was always his go-to goalkeeper for shooting. If that was a goal there, he’d always say he had four squares so I was almost irrelevant as a goalie. It wouldn’t matter where I was, he’d always have it in his mind that it was on him about where he was on the pitch.

"He’d be hitting one of those four squares and he used to hit in early — like a dart — and you just couldn’t save it. He was the best I’ve worked with. It was so good to see him. And he’s been brilliant. His level of detail is superb. You’d be forgiven for thinking: ‘He’s a United legend coming in, is he just a face for it?’ But I’ve been in a couple of meetings and he’s been outstanding."

United saw a record-low eighth-place finish in the 2023/24 Premier League campaign, and will no doubt hope to return to their glory days as soon as possible. Nobody has managed to replicate the successes of Sir Alex Ferguson since he departed Old Trafford in 2013 after a near-27-year reign.

But Ten Hag is optimistic Van Nistelrooy can help Man United get back on track, telling the club website in July: "I am delighted that Rene [Hake] and Ruud have agreed to join our project, adding a wealth of experience, knowledge and new energy to the staff.

"Now is a good time to refresh the coaching team as we look to build on the achievements of the past two years and push to the next level." Also arriving at the club this summer is former Go Ahead Eagles head honcho Rene Hake, who brings 21 years of managerial experience to the table.

New sporting director, Dan Ashworth added: "Together with Erik, we are working to strengthen all areas of our men’s first-team operations, and refreshing the coaching staff is an important part of that. It’s a particular pleasure to welcome Ruud back to the club where he enjoyed so much success as a player, and I know that he and Rene will help reinforce the winning mentality and high standards we are aiming for."

headline: Kylian Mbappe has very been clear what PSG must do amid Marcus Rashford transfer interest
body: Manchester United star Marcus Rashford has already gained Kylian Mbppe's seal of approval, amid links with a move to PSG.

Once considered an indispensable talent at United, Rashford endured a worrying dip in form last season, leading manager Erik ten Hag to come to his defence. The forward missed out on a place in the England squad for Euro 2024 as a result and has since been touted with a move away from Old Trafford, with PSG emerging as a possible destination - though talks have gone quiet in recent weeks.

The French champions have an obvious void to fill in attack after Mbappe finally completed his long-awaited move to Real Madrid this summer. When the pair crossed paths in 2019, Mbappe was full of praise for Rashford, who has been mentioned as his possible successor at the Parc des Princes.

In the second leg of their Champions League clash, United staged a remarkable comeback as a brace from Romelu Lukaku cancelled out PSG's two-goal advantage before Rashford stepped up to the penalty spot in added time to send Ole Gunnar Solskjaer's side through to the quarter-finals. After full-time, Mbappe lauded Rashford's mentality, making it clear that he thinks PSG would be right to try and sign him.
"When you take a penalty in that situation, how much practice you have put on the training ground doesn't matter," he said.

"It's about confidence. He's a player who plays with so much confidence. He's one of the most dangerous forward players in England. Paul Pogba has spoken about how special he is and he doesn't talk about players in such a way often."

The following two seasons saw Rashford score a combined 43 goals in all competitions. He suffered his first major dip in form during the 2021/22 campaign, ending with five goals, due to a mix of injury and illness.

However, he enjoyed his career-best season the following year as Erik ten Hag took the reins at Old Trafford. A phenomenal 30-goal return looked to be the sign of Rashford hitting his peak years- but the forward only managed a meagre eight goals last term.

With Rasmus Hojlund leading the line, Rashford played out wide with only Antony to challenge him on the left flank. Missing out on Euro 2024 and his importance to United taking a hit has led to Rashford's name being mentioned in transfer rumours this summer.

Although it is unlikely that Rashford will leave his boyhood club, PSG have the financial power to make the deal happen. United have reportedly put a £70m-plus price tag on Rashford, who previously attracted interest from the French outfit in 2022.

PSG have lost their global star and could need a new high-profile winger to replace him. With Mbappe aware of the quality that Rashford possesses, the United forward could be the man to replace him, as improbable as it may seem.

headline: Manchester United can get FFP boost at a perfect time for Sir Jim Ratcliffe
body: Manchester United could be reaping the awards in more ways than one for work done in the club’s academy over the past few years.

Head of academy Nick Cox has been praised for his work with the youth teams since being appointed into the role in the summer of 2019. The former Watford and Sheffield United man has been credited with making massive improvements in the academy, and that is now filtering into the first team.

After impressing Erik ten Hag this time last year during pre-season, midfielder Kobbie Mainoo went onto play a key role in the season. His performances earned him a call up to the England team for Euro 2024.

The 19-year-old made a total of 32 first team appearances for United in all competitions last season, scoring five goals. He was hailed for his performance in the FA Cup final against Man City as United came out as 2-1 winners.

History could potentially repeat itself again this year with both Toby Collyer and Harry Amass impressing during pre-season so far. Both players started Sunday’s 3-0 loss against Liverpool, with Amass also being selected for the 3-2 win over Real Betis as well as the friendly vs Arsenal.

Ten Hag has shown with Mainoo that he is not afraid of putting young players in if they impress. That’s a good sign for both Collyer and Amass ahead of the new season, but their development is good news for United, even if they don’t break into the first team.

Their performances mean that clubs will be willing to pay good money if they are sold now or in the future. The fact that they are both academy graduates means that any fee made will go down as pure profit on the club’s accounts.

If that is the case, then it will be a big boost for United given the Premier League’s Profitability and Sustainability Rules (PSRs). Any pure profit made will also come at a time when United need it the most, given the club's recent record on player sales and the money needed for both the new stadium and for incoming transfers.

For United it’s win-win in terms of the improvement in the academy. The club either produces players who can make their way into the first team and reduce the need for incoming transfers, or they can sell for pure profit to boost their finances.

headline: Manchester United might start 17-year-old against Man City after 'aggressive' comment
body: How does it feel to play for Manchester United in front of thousands of fans at just 17 years old?
Just ask Harry Amass, who started against Arsenal, Real Betis and Liverpool on tour in the USA.

"I enjoy it, man," he said. "In front of the crowds, playing with the best players, I’m enjoying it. You’ve just got to show your aggressive side. You might be young, smaller than the opponent, but you have to show you are aggressive and don’t back down. Then you can have a good game."
Amass spoke to Manchester-based reporters in the mixed zone in the Snapdragon Stadium last week and a start against Liverpool in Columbia followed that conversation.

The youngster was asked about a potential start in the Community Shield against Manchester City and said: "No conversations have been had yet, but this pre-season is a chance to prove that if I am picked I can do it. Obviously we’ll see what happens when Luke [Shaw] and Tyrell [Malacia] come back.

"My intention is to play first-team football at this club. I think if the opportunity comes, I’ve got to take it with both hands, it could change my career. I am just waiting for that moment, I am ready."
Luke Shaw started for England in the final of the European Championship against Spain and has been given an extended break, while Tyrell Malacia is still recovering from injury.
Malacia last played a competitive fixture for the Netherlands in June last year and has faced a prolonged period on the sidelines due to a knee injury, which required two rounds of surgery.
The 24-year-old is expected to be available again in two months, which opens the door for Amass, and the London-born full-back intends to capitalise on the opportunity.
After just one year at United, Amass has already drawn comparisons to Shaw, who swapped the South for the North himself when he was a teenager. "It is a good comparison," he said.
"In my opinion, [Shaw is] one of the best left-backs in the Premier League, if not the best for a long time. So I am not gonna complain at the comparisons!"

United thought Shaw had the quality to play at Old Trafford for 10 years when he was signed from Southampton in 2014 and they recognised similar potential in Amass when he was signed from Watford last summer, a move that was considered a coup given the interest from other clubs.

Amass was persuaded to sign for United and hasn't looked back. He was tremendous for the Under-18s last season, playing a key role in a supremely talented team that won a treble, and is now on the cusp of making his senior debut after delivering mature pre-season performances.

Anyone who has watched Amass will understand there can be no concerns about his ability, talent or mentality. He is a technically exceptional, modern-day full-back, but the only question mark against the youngster was whether he was physical enough for senior football.
Amass is diminutive but proved himself on the pre-season tour. His 'aggression' compensates for his lack of stature and he got the better of Mohamed Salah at the weekend.
Malacia won't be involved in the squad for the Community Shield against City on Saturday and Shaw won't have the fitness to play 90 minutes at Wembley.

Amass is almost guaranteed to be involved in some capacity and that will highlight his impressive progress in the space of just a few months, as the youngster only got close to the pitch when he warmed up on the sidelines when he was last at Wembley for the FA Cup semi-final.

Erik ten Hag named Amass, Ethan Wheatley, Habeeb Ogunneye and Louis Jackson on a handful of benches at the end of last season due to the injury crisis and any observers would have noticed how slight they looked, which is normal at their age, in the pre-match warm-ups.
However, what Amass lacks in physicality, he makes up for in character, aggression and talent, so it wouldn't be a surprise to see him start against City in the Community Shield.

headline: 'I've got to take it' - the three Manchester United youngsters set for first team squad roles
body: Joe Hugill was left in the cold at Wigan, Habeeb Ogunneye warmed the bench for nine games, Toby Collyer was an unused substitute on eight occasions and Harry Amass kicked his heels on seven matchdays.

In the end, Ethan Wheatley had the privilege of becoming Manchester United's 250th academy graduate. Wheatley had been on the bench for only two games before he was summoned to replace Rasmus Hojlund for a late cameo against Sheffield United.
"Quite a few of us wanted it and we had a bit of banter about it!" Wheatley says of the 250 milestone. He is stood with Amass and Collyer, both smiling ruefully in the Snapdragon Stadium mixed zone.
Southerners Collyer and Amass are doing their utmost to extend the number to 251 as soon as possible. United expect Collyer, Amass and Wheatley to remain with the squad beyond the transfer window.

Collyer, 20, has started in three of United's four pre-season games and strapped on the captain's armband for the second half against Rosenborg. The 17-year-old Amass has lined up in both tour games in the United States.

Left back Amass followed up his invaluable 45 minutes against Arsenal in Los Angeles, where he was blindsided by Gabriel Jesus for the equalising goal, with a complete performance against Real Betis in San Diego. He capped it with an assist for Amad and drew approval from the crowd with his tenacious tackling.

"I enjoy it, man," the Londoner says. "In front of the crowds, playing with the best players, I’m enjoying it. You’ve just got to show your aggressive side, you might be young, smaller than the opponent, but you have to show you are aggressive and don’t back down. Then you can have a good game."

Amass only joined the United academy from Watford last year. Such was his importance during the run-in last season, Erik ten Hag checked on his well-being in the Carrington canteen when the academy squad returned from their title-clinching win at Wolves in April.

Luke Shaw only played 15 times for United last term and Tyrell Malacia's absence from club football is nearing 15 months. Amass could conceivably start the Community Shield against Manchester City on Saturday.

"No conversations have been had yet," he admits, "but this pre-season is a chance to prove that if I am picked I can do it. Obviously we’ll see what happens when Luke and Tyrell come back. My intention is to play first team football at this club.
"I think if the opportunity comes, I’ve got to take it with both hands, it could change my career. I am just waiting for that moment, I am ready."

Diminutive, fleet-footed and attack-minded, there are obvious parallels with the great Barcelona and Spain left back Jordi Alba. Shaw is another Cockney left back who has settled in Manchester for a decade.

Amass approves of that comparison. "It is a good comparison. In my opinion one of the best left-backs in the Premier League, if not the best for a long time. So I am not gonna complain about the comparison!"

"We have to make progress," Ten Hag said on Amass. "But we all see here a potential where we have seen in previous years, for instance two years ago, Garnacho last season. We had it during last season with Kobbie, but he (Amass) is not that far now at this moment. But if we train him well, if we coach him well, then in three months it's possible that he can be on that point.

"But in this moment he needs to catch up and he has to develop some skills already to play for Manchester United, competing for the highest positions in the league. But with big talent it can go up very quickly and that is very interesting to see if he is capable of doing this."

Collyer, signed from Brighton as an 18-year-old two years ago, trained under Ten Hag as early as September 2022. He is one of only three academy players whose contract signing Ten Hag insisted on attending. The other two were Alejandro Garnacho and Kobbie Mainoo.

"I think it's a massive boost," Collyer says of Ten Hag's attendance for his signing ceremony. "It shows obviously he rates me as a player. Just onwards and upwards really, just got to give my best every day and see what happens."

Collyer came on for half-an-hour at the Snapdragon Stadium and thwarted Betis twice in injury time with valiant interventions. He has acquitted himself impressively and United need to bring down the average age of their midfield department.

"When you're on the bench I think it's really valuable just to be in and around it, experience what it's like on a matchday," Collyer explains. "In the changing room, on the bench, with a crowd, getting used to it. Now I've managed to get quite a lot of minutes in pre-season, so I'm happy.

"I'd say with me, a lot of my work is off the ball as well. Predominantly, I'm a really busy player, I like to get about the pitch and an area of my game I'd like to improve on is in possession. So I think the only way you're going to get better is by demanding the ball, getting on it and not backing away from situations when you could."

Ten Hag made a beeline for Mainoo after United's League Cup victory last year and back at Wembley 15 months later, did likewise with Collyer after United won the FA Cup. "He just said take it all in, enjoy myself and keep working hard and you never know what can happen," Collyer reveals.
"He's a really good guy, the manager. With everyone, he tells you what he wants from each player, he tries his best to help you out, as well as with the other coaching staff as well.
"At the end of the day, they do everything for us and we have to put it out on the pitch and give everything for them."

Stockport-born Wheatley was one of a handful of positives from the listless defeat to Rosenborg last month. He can expect to continue training with the first team amid Rasmus Hojlund's six-week absence with a hamstring strain.

"I'm just taking everything as it comes, to be honest," he cautions. "Obviously, I had a little taste of it last season. This season, I just want to keep my head down, keep developing as a player and keep impressing, so hopefully get more chances.

"The club, its history is of bringing through loads of academy players, the likes of Kobbie, playing with us less than a year ago and breaking into the first team, inspires us and motivates us. Because we know the pathway is there. If we impress, get the chances that will be given at this club we'll take them."

Ruud van Nistelrooy has not rejoined United as a striker coach but Wheatley, born in the same year that Van Nistelrooy left United, is picking his brains. "I think especially since Ruud came in, obviously he was a top striker, he was probably one of the best strikers we've had at the club.
"As soon as he came in I've been trying to take tips off him to help develop my game."

headline: Two players can save Man United millions to create Sir Jim Ratcliffe dream transfer scenario
body: Manchester United have a number of areas that need to be improved, but the club selected three priority areas this summer.

A striker and a centre-back have arrived, while it is thought that Erik ten Hag is closing in on a new midfielder, Manuel Ugarte. While Leny Yoro’s three-month setback could push United into another centre-half signing this window, other positions may need some attention.

One of those is left-back, given how injuries decimated options there last season. Luke Shaw is back to fitness but only played 15 matches last term due to issues and is yet to go through a full season at United without injury.

Meanwhile, Tyrell Malacia is not expected to return until October, having not played in more than a year due to setbacks in his rehabilitation from serious surgery. Sergio Reguilon was acquired on loan last deadline day but returned to Tottenham in January after Ten Hag ended his stay early, with Shaw and Malacia both expected back soon. That never happened.

As a result, Diogo Dalot, Aaron Wan-Bissaka and even Victor Lindelof had to cover in the role with full-back options stretched. Sorting another loan this summer to cover for Malacia would be sensible.

But meanwhile, academy recruit Harry Amass has impressed so far in pre-season, most notably against Real Betis. The 17-year-old joined from Watford last August with big hopes for the future, and the first fruits of his potential are starting to show.

A few first-team stints this coming season followed by consistent progress, and United might not need to find a new left-back when Shaw’s contract runs out in 2027, saving a good few million. For now, third-choice at United is an ample status, and the reality is that the team might still need more experienced cover at left-back via a loanee until Malacia returns.

Another area of debate is the right-wing position. On paper, United have a number of options there, with Antony, Jadon Sancho and Marcus Rashford able to play in the role, Alejandro Garnacho too, albeit to limited effect.

In reality, the spot has hardly been nailed down in Ten Hag’s tenure, with Antony underwhelming his £85m price tag, Rashford preferring the left flank far more, and Sancho falling out with the manager, a feud that has now been quashed.

There has been good reason to suggest that the right wing needs a new addition, but United need not bother. Amad can save United a good few quid in the short term with his assets from the right, as shown against Real Betis.

His breakaway goal against Liverpool in last season’s FA Cup tie showed the raw talent he has, something that former Sunderland boss Tony Mowbray was never shy to underline during Amad’s 14-goal loan spell at the Black Cats two seasons ago.
Amad has now scored twice in pre-season, for what that is worth. His goal against Rangers might have felt sweet given his torrid former prior loan spell in Scotland.

But it was against Real Betis that he showed what he can do when he has minutes under his belt, scoring United’s second of the game after winning a penalty for their first. After recovering from a long-term injury in time for the second half of the season, Amad only managed to start the final three league games.

headline: Alexander Isak comparison, Arsenal fury - Man United sent exciting Chido Martin-Obi verdict
body: Manchester United are closing in on the signing of promising young talent Chido Martin-Obi after the youngster turned down a new contract at Premier League rivals Arsenal. The Gunners are said to have pulled out all the stops to tie the 16-year-old down to fresh terms, but it's United who look set to win the race for the Denmark-born striker.

Obi-Martin, who scored 29 goals in 17 league matches for Arsenal's Under-18s last year, went from strength to strength last season, notably scoring 10 goals in a single game against Liverpool. It's understood United's head of the academy, Nick Cox, and the head of academy recruitment, Luke Fedorenko, are the main driving forces behind the deal.

Once the i's have been dotted and the t's crossed, it will be a significant coup for United's youth set-up which has been undergoing a renaissance after a period of underachieving and Cox's appointment as head of academy in 2019 was a key moment.

The Manchester Evening News spoke with football.london's chief Arsenal writer Kaya Kaynak for an insight into Martin-Obi, his understanding of the deal and what sort of player he is ahead of his arrival in Manchester.

Kaya Kaynak: "It's a bit hard to say as he's still so young, but one thing he seems to be very good at is scoring goals. He's quite a bit taller than most others around his age group right now and looks stylistically a bit similar to Alexander Isak with his languid running and technical ability."
KK: "Arsenal were really keen to keep him. They pulled out all the stops and were confident of doing so after keeping other young talents like Ethan Nwaneri and Myles Lewis-Skelly in recent years.
"However, they do feel they offered all they were willing to offer. With that in mind, there's a feeling of acceptance at the decision Chido has decided to take."

KK: "Any player who scores as many goals as Chido did at such a young age is going to be thought of very highly. It's probably fair to say was viewed as one of the top three or four prospects right now.

"Arsenal are constantly using internal analytics to assess the trajectory of their players and he did look to be a promising talent. At the same time though, it's so hard to tell at 16 and many were intrigued to see how he would have coped at a higher age level."
KK: "I'd say so. There's clearly a high-potential player in there. He's someone who can score lots of goals and that's not easy to find.
"The big test for him will be seeing how he steps up through the age groups. If he manages that though, United have a real player on their hands."
KK: "I think the fact that he was in such high demand this summer tells you what a good player he is. He was wanted by clubs across Europe as well as in England."

headline: Dan Ashworth makes encouraging Man United gesture after Sir Jim Ratcliffe admission
body: Dan Ashworth has met with Manchester United Women's players after a turbulent summer for Marc Skinner's side.

United have come in for criticism of late number after a number of high-profile players, including England goalkeeper Mary Earps and captain Katie Zelem, were allowed to leave the club on free transfers, while co-owner Sir Jim Ratcliffe sparked controversy when he admitted plans for the women's team were "TBC".

Fan frustration was further compounded when it emerged Skinner's side were set to be moved out of their state-of-the-art training facility to accommodate the men's team while a £50m refurbishment of their Carrington facilities was underway.

However, Ashworth's long-awaited arrival from Newcastle United last month has offered some cause for optimism, with the sporting director having previously been a huge advocate for the growth of the women's game during his time with the Magpies and in his previous role at Brighton & Hove Albion. And the 53-year-old has now met with Skinner and his players as they ramp up their pre-season preparations at St George's Park.

Pictures shared on the club's website show Ashworth giving a speech to the women's first-team squad and shaking hands with stars such as Ella Toone and Millie Turner. This comes after he outlined his vision for the Reds in an open letter to supporters.

“Delivering a successful women’s team and a thriving, productive academy are both key objectives of my job, and I have a strong background in both areas," Ashworth said last month. "Women’s football was an important part of my remit in past roles with Newcastle United, Brighton & Hove Albion and the FA, and it will be the same at Manchester United.

"Women’s football is arguably the most exciting area of growth in the global game, and we want to be part of that. Last season’s FA Cup win was a fantastic landmark as our first major women’s trophy, and how we want to build on that with Marc, his staff and the players."
United finished fifth in the Women's Super League (WSL) last term and won the Women's FA Cup. They will get their new campaign underway against West Ham at Old Trafford on Saturday, September 22.

headline: Manchester United confirm 'insane' summer transfer as overhaul continues
body: Manchester United have confirmed the signing of Canada international Simi Awujo on a three-year deal.

The 20-year-old midfielder joins the Reds from the United States collegiate system, where she represented the University of Southern California’s USC Trojans. Awujo made her senior international debut for Canada at 18-years-old and has 19 caps for her country to date, reaching the quarter-finals of this summer’s Paris 2024 Olympic games.

Reflecting on her move to Manchester, Awujo said: “To say that I’m a professional footballer for Manchester United is insane. I’m so excited for the season ahead, what the future holds here and just to be a red devil. I cannot wait to play in front of the great Manchester United fans.”

Manager Marc Skinner added: “Simi is an exciting young talent who we are delighted has chosen to continue her football journey with us here at Manchester United. Our wonderful fans can expect a midfielder with international pedigree, who will only develop further in our competitive English game.”

Awujo is United's fifth signing of the summer following the arrivals of Dominique Janssen, Melvine Malard, Elisabeth Terland and Anna Sandber. headline: Mary Earps takes subtle swipe at Manchester United after PSG move
body: England goalkeeper Mary Earps says she is hoping to add "a few more trophies to the cabinet" after leaving Manchester United to join Paris Saint-Germain (PSG).

Earps joined the Reds in 2019 and helped the club win the FA Cup last year. However, the shot-stopper opted to embark on a new chapter when her contract expired in June after a disappointing Women's Super League (WSL) campaign saw United finished fifth last term - 21 points worse off than in the previous campaign.

Despite being linked with a move to Arsenal, Earps chose to join PSG, who have qualified for the Women's Champions League for six consecutive seasons. Speaking on the latest episode of the BBC's Tooney & Russo Show, Earps said she has established some "great relationships" in Manchester, but her decision to leave was fueled by "the opportunity to play for a great team in top competitions" and be "in a position to win silverware".

"It's like an itch you can never scratch enough,” Earps said. And the 31-year-old's former United teammate Ella Toone, who also plays alongside Earps for the Lionesses, was full of praise for the goalkeeper.
"She deserves everything," said Toone. "Mary's dream - and it always has been - is to play at the highest level, play in the Champions League and that's what she's done."

Earps is not the only player to have left United this summer, with captain Katie Zelem and forward Lucia Garcia also having departed. Reflecting last month on her decision to move overseas, Earps wrote on Instagram: "The club is about to undergo a period of transition, and unfortunately I don’t feel it aligns with the timing of where I’m at in my career, therefore I think now is the right time to make a change and embark on a new challenge."

headline: Manchester United sign Sweden defender in record-breaking transfer
body: Manchester United have confirmed the signing of highly-rated Sweden international Anna Sandberg on three-year deal, with the option of a further year.

The defender joins the Reds from BK Hacken, where she had been playing since July 2022, gaining Champions League experience with the Damallsvenskan side. On the international stage, Sandberg was part of the Sweden squad that finished third at the 2023 FIFA Women’s World Cup.

She joins for what will be a record transfer fee for a Swedish women’s player, surpassing the £150,000 Everton paid to Rosengard for Hanna Bennison in 2021. The 21-year-old full-back is United's fourth signing of the summer, following the arrivals of Dominique Janssen, Elisabeth Terland and Melvine Malard.
“I’m very happy and grateful to sign for this big club, Manchester United," Sandberg said. "I hope I can help our team with my qualities and deliver many winning moments for our fantastic fans.”

Manager Marc Skinner added: “We are delighted to have Anna join our Manchester United family. She is a talented young player, who already has a wealth of international and Champions League experience. We look forward to seeing her develop further in red.”

United finished fifth in the Women's Super League (WSL) last season and won the Women's FA Cup. They will get their 2024/25 campaign underway against West Ham United at Old Trafford on the weekend of September 21/22.
